body.p: Sustainability plans adapt over time. This document is intended to capture snapshots of Simal's sustainability plans as the project progresses.

Simal is a framework for building systems for use by organisations that need to inform the communities around a group of related projects. It was initiated in March 2007 with the OSS Watch team based at Oxford University Computing Services.

section.title: March 2007
section.p: Having started Simal to meet a specific need within the OSS Watch project plan (see Project History), it makes sense that the initial sustainability plan for Simal involves a portion of OSS Watch's funded effort. The initial plan distinguishes between short-term, mid-term, and long-term sustainability, but does not specify dates for these divisions.

section.title: Short-term
section.p: The project was always intended to build a voluntary development community around itself. However, a direct contribution of OSS Watch staff time is required to see Simal through from its initial inception to its presence on a publicly accessible hosted development environment. That contribution is estimated at 0.1 FTE (full time equivalent) over 4 months.
In addition, OSS Watch staff are contributing voluntary effort on evenings and weekends to the project.
Since the funded committment to the project is finite, the first order of business is to develop a viable development community.

section.title: Mid-term
section.p: At some point in the not too distant future Simal will be a fully functioning project. At that point its outputs will undoubtedly be in use on the OSS Watch site, and hopefully some other sites. It may be possible at that point in time to apply for project-specific funding from JISC or some other funding body in order to sustain direct OSS Watch staff contribution to Simal. However, the project needs to anticipate that funding will not be forthcoming. It therefore needs to have a viable and growing voluntary development community in place.

section.title: Long-term
section.p: At this point it is difficult to guess where Simal might go under the influence of a consensus-based development community. Long term sustainability at this point sees that community continuing to develop Simal in order to meet its own needs.

section.title: Exit Strategies
section.p: There are a number of possible exit strategies Simal. These might arise as real possibilities at different points within the project.

ul.li: the Simal community flourishes and continues to develop Simal along its present path
the Simal community seeks to transform Simal into an Apache Incubator project or as part of some other software foundation

section.p: These are by no means the only possible exit strategies for Simal. This list will be revised and expanded as new possibilities emerge over the course of the project.
